title: Software Architecture Notes
description: From basic diagrams and responsibilities through to microservices, events, CQRS, cloud native systems and digitalisation architecture.

levels.title: Architecture Foundations
levels.summary: Start from what architecture is for, and how to think about components, boundaries and responsibilities in small systems.
learningOutcomes: Explain in simple terms what software architecture is and why it matters.
Describe basic building blocks such as components, interfaces and data flows.
Read and sketch simple architecture diagrams such as layered and client server views.
Relate architecture decisions to non functional needs such as performance, security and reliability.

levels.title: Applied Architecture
levels.summary: Layered patterns, microservices, events, data ownership and real trade offs between coupling, performance and changeability.
learningOutcomes: Describe and compare common architectural styles such as layered systems, microservices and event driven designs.
Explain key runtime qualities such as scalability, resilience and maintainability with concrete examples.
Use simple patterns such as CQRS, event sourcing and message queues in realistic scenarios.
Discuss trade offs between different designs for a given problem.

levels.title: Digital and Cloud Scale Architecture
levels.summary: Event driven systems, CQRS, integration patterns, observability and digitalisation strategy across whole organisations.
learningOutcomes: Connect architecture work to digitalisation strategy, organisational change and long term evolution of systems.
Explain how architecture governance, roadmaps and standards guide delivery teams without blocking them.
Reason about architecture in regulated and safety critical contexts in plain language.
Describe a realistic end to end path from idea to production for complex digital systems.

summaryPage.title: Software Architecture summary and games
summaryPage.description: A recap and playful space to join up diagrams, patterns and digitalisation ideas with small applied challenges.

targetAudience: People who want to move from writing code to thinking like software architects.
Students and professionals working in digitalisation, data and integration.
Teams and lecturers who want ready made diagrams, tools and scenarios for teaching architecture.
